solution.sample:
Rule-based systems would need an explicit rule to help translate a pronoun like 'elle' in example (1a). The rule might say "find the most recent noun in the sentence; check if it is animate; if yes, translate 'elle' as 'she'; if not, translate 'elle' as 'it'." The system would need to have a lot of explicit linguistic knowledge to do this however.
 
Data-driven MT systems learn from data, so perhaps they simply learn the most frequent translation of 'elle' from the training data? And the most frequent translation of 'elle' could be 'it' rather than 'she'. 
 
Neural MT systems process whole sentences at a time, and this should make the translation of words like 'elle' easier. They also have clever ways of paying attention to the most important words in the training data when translating a particular word, so an NMT system might learn to translate 'elle' as 'it' in precisely the kind of situation that comes up in sentence (1a).

params.taskDescription:
French has grammatical gender. This means that all nouns are assigned either feminine or masculine gender, and this often has little or nothing to do with biological sex. The moon ('la lune') is feminine in French, for example, but the sun ('le soleil') is masculine. If we use a pronoun to refer back to the same entity as a noun already used, we have to respect the gender of that noun. So, in the sentence:

 

(1a) La lune paraît blanche la journée parce qu'elle est voilée par le bleu du ciel. 

(1b) The moon appears white during the day because it is obscured by the blue of the sky.

 

the pronoun 'elle' agrees in gender with 'la lune'.

If 'elle' was being used to talk about a person, for example,  it would normally be translated as 'she' in English. But in cases where 'elle' is used simply to agree with a preceding feminine noun like 'lune', it is translated using 'it', as in the example above.

Do you think the fact that 'elle' is commonly translated as 'she' or as 'it' will cause problems for machine translation?
params.placeholderText: How would a rule-based system handle pronoun translation? Does learning from real translation data make problems like this easier to solve? Does it help that in neural MT whole sentences are processed in one go?

solution.sample:
The pronoun 'il' appears at the beginning of the sentence in (2a) so there is no preceding co-text on which basis 'it' can be predicted over 'he' (and 'him').
 
We cannot come to any conclusions about how machine translation in general or Google Translate in particular 'handles pronouns' based on one example. We would need much more evidence. And note that DeepL gets the translation of 'il' as 'it' correct.
 
The same applies to the question of 'bias'. We would need to test Google Translate using a variety of sentences, some where 'il' should be translated as 'he' and an equal number where 'il' should be translated as 'it'. Likewise we would have to also test the system using a variety of sentences in which 'elle' should be translated as 'she' and others where where 'elle' should be translated as 'it'.

params.taskDescription:
Now consider the examples in (2a) below, and its translation into English by Google Translate in (2b) and and DeepL in (2c):

 

(2a) Ce qu'il faut comprendre lorsqu'un algorithme reconnaît un objet dans une image, c'est que ce même algorithme ne comprend pas du tout la nature de cet objet. Il ne procède que par recoupement avec des exemples qu'on lui aura présentés auparavant. (source: http://www.slate.fr/story/183020/tech-intelligence-artificielle-ia-chat-etre-humain-marche-reconnaissance-objet-experience-sensible)

 

(2b) What must be understood when an algorithm recognizes an object in an image is that this same algorithm does not understand at all the nature of this object. He only proceeds by cross-checking with examples that will have been presented to him previously. (source: Google Translate, 08 December 2021)

 

(2c) What you have to understand when an algorithm recognises an object in an image is that the algorithm does not understand the nature of the object at all. It only cross-checks with examples that have been presented to it beforehand. (source: DeepL, 08 December 2021)

 

  • Can you diagnose the problem with Google Translate's translation of the masculine pronoun 'il' in (2b)? (Note that 'algorithme' is a masculine noun in French.)
  • Does this error mean that machine translation can't handle pronouns?
  • Or is Google Translate biased towards male pronouns in English, even in cases where a non-gendered pronoun is more appropriate?
